awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Design of Two-sided Markets In Dynamic and Uncertain Environments: Theoretical and Operational Issues
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to study the design of two-sided markets in dynamic and uncertain settings. The population of agents in the system evolves over time due to stochastic arrivals to both sides of the market. Agents report their preferences upon entering the system, and either accept or reject match offers based on the compatibility of preferences as well as value of future options. The primary goal of this award is to design such marketplaces in an efficient way by taking into account dynamic interaction, uncertainty and forward looking behavior of agents. The research approach is to compute each agent's expected benefit from remaining unmatched as a utility promise from the market designer under a given policy, which will enable an algorithm for (dynamically) individually-rational match offers. The algorithm will be generalized to the environment where agents may not know their true preferences over matches before the match and there are multiple matches generated on both sides. Further analysis will endow agents with straightforward incentives for truthful behavior and consider the possibility that a market designer learns about agent preferences by observing their responses to match offers while the agents learn about the distribution of available partners by observing the offers they get.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in the layout of markets where there is a need to match two-sided populations of agents such as labor markets, organ transplant, child adoption, and foster care. The award can provide modeling and analysis tools to maximize the efficiency of the matching system and the welfare of its participants. The research is made possible by combining tools developed both in matching/market design in economics and those commonly used in operations. The mathematics developed will also help train graduate and undergraduate students as well as contribute to an ongoing private public partnership between Carnegie Mellon and Pennsylvania Adoption Exchange (PAE).

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to study the design of two-sided markets in dynamic and uncertain settings. Many matching markets are inherently dynamic: Participants arrive in the market over time and interact dynamically before forming matches. We try to maximize the efficiency of the matching mechanisms by taking into account dynamic interaction, uncertainty, and forward-looking behavior of the agents.

Our results are extremely general. They affect on-line marketplaces, healthcare, organ transplants, and any other situation where customers arrive randomly and wait to be matched with providers or sellers. 

In the first thrust of our project, we investigate the most basic question agents ask in congested markets, which is whether or not to join the market. On each side of the queue there is one type of customer that arrives dynamically to the system. Upon arriving at the system, potential customers on each side of the queue make rational join-or-balk decisions to maximize their expected utility. The expected utility of customers joining equals their matching reward, minus the price they pay to join (matching), minus their expected equilibrium delay cost while waiting for a match. Customers can observe the state of the system from the time of arrival until they leave the system and are free to abandon anytime they want. The platform controls through pricing both the 'split' of the two-sided queue and the resulting system size. We study and compare these decisions and the resulting performance under two standard platform objectives, revenue maximization and social welfare maximization. We find that under the revenue-optimal queue split, it is revenue-optimal to operate a one-sided queue, by `splitting’ the queue in `all-or-nothing fashion'. We find that the socially optimal service levels of the two sides are proportional to their delay costs. Hence, the optimality condition for the welfare-maximizing queue split matches the ‘critical fractile’ condition for the optimal service level in the Newsvendor problem. 

In a second thrust of our work, we focus on information control (no control of demand and supply). We consider on each side two agent classes; one is perfectly impatient (leaves if there is a queue), the other has finite patience modeled by a linear delay cost. We compare the match rate (system throughput) under three information regimes, show queue to both sides, hide queue from both sides, and show one hide the other side. We demonstrate that it is strategically advantageous to withhold delay information from one side, especially when it consists of a substantial number of relatively delay-insensitive users. 

In a third thrust of our project, we improve the Pennsylvania Adoption Exchange (PAE) matching process. This is a real-world application of our analytical results to the problem of a match recommendation system to find families for children in state custody. PAE helps case workers representing children in state custody by recommending prospective families for adoption. We provide PAE employees and managers with new advanced decision analysis tools to aid their efforts to find permanent homes for children. These tools allowed them to experiment by assigning different weights to different attributes.

A fourth thrust of our project deals with ranking policies to determine the relative priority between heterogeneous agents. One specific application is the allocation of deceased donor livers to patients with primary liver cancer, i.e., Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC), and patients with end-stage liver disease (ESLD). Another application is to overcome height-based inequity in liver transplants, where shorter patients (and women due to smaller stature) are disadvantaged because they can receive organs from a smaller donor pool due to organ size incompatibility. In both applications, the disadvantaged patient group needs bonus points to increase their priority. We formulate an optimal control problem to minimize waitlist deaths subject to an explicit constraint to equalize transplant rates. The interpretation of the shadow prices of the optimization problem as bonus points is novel in the organ transplantation context and gives rise to easy-to-use and objective methods to calculate those bonus points. An important component of this problem involves developing a simulation model to test policies obtained by analytical results and the use of clinical data in parameter estimation.

This project has several Broader Impact outcomes. The project delivered implementable solutions for public service institutions such as PAE. The new risk index that we have derived for primary liver cancer (HCC) is a tool that can help liver transplant programs recognize which of their listed HCC candidates are the most likely to drop out, and therefore those that need to be transplanted most urgently.

The project contributed to the training of several Ph.D. students, Mehmet Aydemir, Siddharth Singh, and Musa Celdir, who were trained for a career in academia. The project also helped train two postdoctoral researchers, Zachary Leung and Mohammad Delasay, who accepted tenure-track faculty positions at the City University of Hong Kong and Stony Brook University, respectively.
